results.title: Homosexuality: a film for discussion
results.brief_description: Designed to dispel the myths about homosexuality. Homosexuals talk about their lives, their relationships and the difficulties of growing up gay in an oppressive, intolerant society. Parents of gays speak out and the Melbourne public expresses its view on the subject.

results.title: Behind the menu
results.brief_description: A survey of the use of gas in commercial cooking and industrial establishments. The film includes glimpses of what happens “behind the menu” at establishments like the Menzies Hotel, The Royal Melbourne Hospital, the canteen at General Motors and a biscuit factory.

results.title: Here's your bike, Ed!
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, John Taylor, Taylormade Films and Vic Roads
results.brief_description: The purpose of this title is to demonstrate a variety of skills that children need to cycle safely on roads. Designed to accompany a Bike Ed program in schools, with Teacher’s notes, there are a variety of activities and drills which will develop children’s confidence as bike riders and users of the road.

results.title: Go for it!
results.creator_credit: Barwon Youth Employment Office for the Employment Access Program, Community Services Victoria and Clayton Jacobson
results.brief_description: A program aimed at young disadvantaged youth in the labour market, particularly those attending Youth Training Centres, Youth Welfare Services, living in hostels or in the care and custody of Community Services Victoria. Highlights young people succeeding in various jobs and through interviews discusses how they found employment, their expectations and experiences in the workforce.

results.title: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Suzanne Baker Productions, New South Wales. Premier's Dept. Disability Services Co-ordination Unit, New South Wales Film Corporation and Bob Kingsbury
results.brief_description: Designed to improve awareness of intellectually disabled offenders in the criminal justice system, given that this group comprise a disproportionate percentage of both the prison population and juvenile offenders held in institutions. Re-enacts a shop lifting offence by an intellectually disabled youth and follows the case from initial apprehension by the store detective and police interviewing to the arrest and court proceedings. Emphasises the importance of liason with community agencies.
results.title_for_label: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities

results.title: Timber
results.brief_description: A survey of the forests from which Australia obtains timber supplies for firewood, building and other industrial purposes. Illustrates tree-felling and the various methods used to transport logs to timber-mills. Overviews the preservation of natural forests and revegetation programs.

results.title: Professional Development
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Case studies in effective schooling”.
Case studiesin effective schooling presents first hand accounts of how individual schools have gone about improving their effectiveness. “Professional development” is the second part in the series and records the manner in which Ivanhoe East Primary School supports its educational program with a coherent, planned program of professional development for its staff.

results.title: Discovering the Murray-Darling Basin
results.creator_credit: Kenyon Castle, Murray-Darling Basin Commission (Australia) and Kenyon Castle Productions
results.brief_description: Mike Hayes presents this video which shows the immense variety of Australia’s most important agricultural region, stretching from Queensland to South Australia. Not only is the area important agriculturally, but it is also an area of great beauty, rich in wildlife, history and folk lore. Produced for the Murray-Darling Basin Commission the program stresses that almost everybody in Australia is dependent in some way on this vast area and that therefore we should be working to prevent further degradation and repair some of the damage which has already been done.

results.title: Film work
results.creator_credit: John Hughes and Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit.
results.brief_description: This film recalls the work of the Waterside Workers’ Federation Film Unit. Financed by several trade unions, the Unit produced eleven (mainly documentary) films between 1953-58. There are excerpts from four of the films ‘Pensions for Veterans’, ‘The Hungry Miles’, ‘November Victory’ and ‘Hewers of Coal’ and interviews with the Unit members, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Jock Levy. (Awards: ATOM 1982)
